issues.description: Constructor signature for StockIngredient is inconsistent between the problem statement / solution and the template. The UML and the solution expect a constructor StockIngredient(String, int, int), and the example usage in Main (commented) also instantiates StockIngredient with three arguments. However, the template's StockIngredient only provides a four-parameter constructor StockIngredient(String, int, int, boolean). This prevents students from creating StockIngredient instances using the three-argument form shown in the specification and solution and will cause compilation errors or confusion when following the exercise examples.
issues.suggested_fix: Provide a three-argument constructor StockIngredient(String name, int price, int quantity) in the template (either by adding an overloaded constructor that delegates to the existing logic or by replacing the four-argument constructor). This will match the UML, the example usage in Main, and the solution implementation, avoiding compilation errors and student confusion.

issues.description: The problem statement (and the solution implementation) specify a StockIngredient constructor with three parameters: StockIngredient(String, int, int). However, the template repository's StockIngredient class only provides a four-parameter constructor StockIngredient(String, int, int, boolean strictValidation). This signature mismatch prevents a direct mapping from the problem description to the template API and will likely cause compilation errors or confusion when students implement SealSaloon (which and tests expect to create StockIngredient instances with three arguments).
issues.suggested_fix: Provide the three-parameter constructor in the template to match the problem statement and solution. For example, add an overloaded constructor: public StockIngredient(String name, int price, int quantity) { this(name, price, quantity, false); } This preserves the template's existing behavior while aligning signatures across all artifacts.
